reviews.text: Paul Mescal knows how to squeeze the sentiment (is it those puppy-dog eyes?) and give the story more than a little heft. He’s good in the arena, too, and captures just enough of Russell Crowe’s swagger to make you believe there’s a connection.
All battle and fight scenes are expertly choreographed with surprise moves and situations__here’s where the film stands on its own.
Filmmaker Scott's visuals are as sumptuous (and obviously expensive) as usual, but this is plainly a rehash of familiar material.
We already saw this vision for a Romanic swords-and-sandals epic 24 years ago.
...a predominantly (and disappointingly) underwhelming sequel...
Still very much a big-screen spectacle that spends two and a half hours unsuccessfully trying to justify its existence.

As product, Gladiator II emulates both peplum entertainment and the classics. Mescal’s Lucius is a runty hero, Denzel’s undignified hamminess falls short of Shakespearean grandeur, and only the small roles achieve human dimension.
Ridley Scott's 'Gladiator' follow-up is timely and appropriately angry, but its reverence for the original film's protagonist eventually undercuts its narrative and its convictions.

I walked out of the theater wondering who exactly was this film for ... toga bros? Despite an epic scale it felt as if there was no "there" in this overlong sword and sandals complexity. If there is metaphor in the rise and fall of Rome, here we are.
See it for the spectacle.
For all its faults, Gladiator II is an extraordinary film, the kind that demands to be seen in theaters.
As the wackiest, most bloodthirsty Roman emperors seem to have lodged themselves in the public imagination, Scott gives the people what they want.

And, although the film falls short of the heights achieved by its predecessor, it is nevertheless a serviceable swords-and-sandals adventure and arguably the most entertaining film Scott has made in the past nine years.
In a cast of veteran actors and extremely talented up-and-comers, Washington steals the movie. He takes the throne.
Fast, brutal and absorbing, the shocker opener sets the template for the rest of the movie, which plays — and often feels — like one long, inventively diverse, elaborately imaginative fight.

There’s something real in history that Gladiator II gestures toward subtly without mentioning it explicitly more than once. It’s the looming transformation of Rome from pagan decadence and conquering bloodlust to an unlikely accelerant of Christianity.
Denzel Washington is the main reason why Gladiator II surpasses its original... [Full review in Spanish]

Someone saw the “how often dudes think about the Roman empire” TikTok shenanigans and said “Get Ridley on the phone.” And Ridley said, “I’ll only do it if we can fill the colosseum with water and have the gladiators fight sharks.”

The sheer force of talent in front of and behind the camera ultimately wins out, and drawbacks aside, this is a movie you’ll want to experience on a massive screen. Let Ridley Scott’s directorial prowess wash over you, and you won’t be disappointed.
Paul Mescal just seems overwhelmed. At a lot of points, this film winds up feeling like an echo of the first film.
This movie belongs to Denzel Washington. It was campier than the first one, and consequently I liked it better.
The story and drama of Gladiator II may be fairly dull, but its superb action, visual spectacle and outlandish historical inaccuracy are where the film truly shines.
Watch it purely for Denzel's performance.
I wasn't the biggest fan of Paul Mescal's performance and the somewhat lackluster battle scenes, Denzel brings enough energy and fun to the screen to make this an entertaining watch.

This film is "Fresh" strictly off of the performance of the great Denzel Washington. He elevates everyone around him in each scene he appears in. Despite its long run-time and forced callbacks to the first film, this is a solid watch because of Denzel.
This sequel manages to be its own thing, and its jaded attitude feels right for the moment.
If it doesn't quite match the staggering highs of Crowe's biggest movie star moments in the original, it comes pretty close.

Instead of amplifying a by-the-numbers story with Pascal & Washington just waiting with more well-rounded ambition and arcs, it focuses entirely on the wrong protagonist, a basic revenge-driven Maximus-lite through action more ridiculous than adrenalized.
It's Washington who ultimately makes "Gladiator II" stand apart from the first film and makes it a lot more fun than it has any right to be.
It can't fill "Gladiator's" sandals.
Where the original was a masterpiece of grit, vengeance, and sweeping drama, this sequel feels like it’s been cobbled together from a last minute brainstorm of, "What if we just... added sharks?"
There’s an interesting throughline between the two films that, while they both have different identities that favor a progression in time, make sense together in a franchise.
Impresses with stunning visuals and a stellar cast but struggles to match the emotional depth and originality of its predecessor, leaving mixed impressions despite its ambition.
Ridley Scott’s sequel is entertaining, but it feels more like a remake.

Gladiator II is a solid entertaining popcorn blockbuster story of rage, strength and honor with grisly impressive battle sequences but it still falls into the shadows of the monumental standards set by its predecessor.
In the end, Gladiator II doesn’t live up to the Academy Award-winning Gladiator, but it is a solid addition to the family story and history.

Gladiator II is fine, it’s a big spectacle executed mostly well, it has a number of pretty fun and/or good performances, Paul Mescal is certainly a movie star, and Denzel Washington is having the time of his life. Are you not reasonably entertained?
Paul Mescal and Denzel Washington's performances are the clear standouts in Sir Ridley Scott's sequel.

I found this movie to be entertaining, a heady mixture of action and drama. It is very well acted by the lead actors, with strong supporting performances. Ridley Scott's direction, and production values are both solid, and the movie looks just great.
Without his [Ridley Scott's] iconic visual eye or his interest in anti-capitalist stories, Gladiator II feels like his most anonymous film in decades.
If you are looking for big spectacle entertainment it works
There’s ambition in “Gladiator II,” to be sure. There’s also a temptation to burden itself with the mere implications of conflict so we can’t see the absence of conflicts' roots.

Mescal’s Lucius doesn’t quite live up to Crowe’s Maximus, but he has his moments, and Scott directs this with so much exuberance. After a shaky start, featuring a scattered plot, it finds its footing and balances its emotions beautifully.
You WILL be entertained.
The scale of the distractions correlates to the scale of dissoluteness and corruption. It’s almost as if history repeats itself.
It’s aggressively fun, nothing more and occasionally less.
It’s bonkers, but in a very good way, indeed.
That insistence in creating parallels between the two “Gladiator” films—and between Lucius and Maximus—occasionally yields poetic results, though in general the outcome is contrived.
"'Are you  not entertained!?' - no, I'm not, but some people will be."

Gladiator II whisks its audience away to the past while reflecting on the present and future. Could it have improved what we’ve witnessed before beyond simply tweaking parts here and there? Yes. But it’s one hell of an entertaining show.
Gladiator II exudes so much … Capital-M Movie … that you are forgiving of the shadow the original casts over it.
It’s thoroughly mediocre, not worthy of being reviled or glorified.
Gladiator II commits the cardinal sin of legacy sequels: it adds something that actually diminishes the original. That is the film’s true travesty. And no, with that, I was not entertained.
I liked the sharks. That's about it.
A sequel fighting for two-and-a-half hours to justify its existence.

It’s quite epic, engaging, and worth a trip to the theater. Minus some bizarre CG primate and shark additions in the ring that take you out a bit, it really is a worthy sequel that will keep you into the thrill of it all.
Feels messy and unfocused; a narrative content to live in the past, in search of a hero who never really rises.
The concept of following Lucius’ homecoming had potential, but it doesn’t quite fulfill his father’s promise to return glory to Rome.

dared to make jumping the shark into an entertaining, literal and spectacle filled challenge. If you love it when someone embraces melodramatic ridiculousness and goes over the top, then you will love “Gladiator II.”

Best of all, as usual, is Denzel Washington. You can see he’s having a ball as the crafty, conniving, chuckling villain Macrinus. But he isn’t hammy or over-the-top; it’s a sly, subtle, carefully wrought performance.
Ridley Scott's return to the coliseum is an entertaining, imperfect mosaic of tones and ideas that never quite fit together.

Some of Mescal's best roles are his quietest, where we can imagine the complicated thoughts dancing behind his sad eyes. It's strange then, to see him super-sized into this heroic He-Man of a warrior, slicing and dicing nameless centurions.
Mescal is easy to root for, soft-spoken and soft-eyed, convincing in the fight scenes, and holding the screen with authority even when paired with Denzel Washington, the movie’s real draw.
While this sequel remains consistently watchable, Scott and Scarpa (who recently collaborated on the disastrous Napoleon) never catch the electrifying vibe of its progenitor.

Instead of the sword-and-sandal thrills of solemn and deadly gladiatorial contests in the Roman arena, we get cartoonish computer-generated excesses that are more ludicrous each time the gladiators step out into the ring.

If you’re paying attention, despite the copious gore, Denzel Washington having the time of his life as a scenery-chewing villain, and of course the sharks, you’ll leave the movie with a far deeper grasp of Rome as it actually was.
Thanks to the actors who play them, Lucius and Marcus are affable chaps, but you can’t imagine why anyone would follow either of them into the ring.
It could've stirred a conversation to add needed density to this simplistic popcorn blockbuster encased in middling CGI and an underwritten and frankly dull lead.

The only surprise is that Mr. Scott, who has directed four movies in the last five years despite being in his mid-eighties... has chosen to devote his dotage to channeling fury like this. But it, and his star, are absolutely equal to the moment.
It all works, and it's all because of Denzel.
To believe in (and enjoy) Gladiator II is to suspend all knowledge on the Roman Empire and ignore everything about great storytelling… I simply cannot do it.

Denzel Washington especially seems to be having a blast, hamming it up panto style as a plotting Iago-esque figure who steals every scene he’s in -- no mean feat considering how clunky the majority of the dialogue is. Solid, if overly broody.

Gladiator II won’t have the lasting power of Gladiator. It’s a well-made & very entertaining sequel, but it’s chained to a hackneyed script. Scott proves that he still has the directorial expertise to turn average scripts into above-average movies though.
Gladiator 2 is the one movie this year other than Wicked that absolutely been screened on a big screen! Denzel Washington delivers the crown jewel of his career with the cinematic gift of  Macrinus.
It seems that this time around, Scott sacrificed soul for spectacle. There is a decent amount excitement here, but precious little emotion.
Like Scott's last film, the curiously untethered Napoleon, Gladiator II is a display of elephantine emptiness.  No wonder it feels about 45 minutes too long.
The good part about all of the overindulgences Scott granted himself in making “Gladiator 2” is that this is all piled upon a very solid foundation.

It's an eye-popping, barbaric, sword-and-sandal, cinematic spectacle, featuring ferocious baboons, a saddled rhino and savage sharks...along with scene-stealing Denzel Washington, who should get a Best Supporting Actor Oscar nomination.
If you're going to see Gladiator II, go see it in the biggest screen possible.
Gladiator is a masterpiece, while Gladiator 2 is simply a sword-and-sandals action flick you'll forget about almost instantly.
It's bigger, badder, and more violent... (with) Denzel doing his Macrinus thing (and) having the best time ever... Spectacle is the point... less serious, more entertaining.
Paul Mescal, as Lucius, the muscular adult son of original "Gladiator" hero Russell Crowe, is supposed to be the star, but he gets upstaged almost from the get-go.

Rome lives and breathes through Scott’s bravura filmmaking and Scarpa’s incisive script…Throw in a fiery Paul Mescal and a Denzel Washington performance for the ages, and you have the most entertaining big screen blockbuster of the year.
History might keep repeating itself, but there's no reason for cinematic retreads to be this tiresome too.

A worthy successor to the original Best Picture film. Definitely entertains via spectacle, blood, nostalgia and an excellent cast, that includes a brilliant Denzel Washington stealing every scene. [Full review in Spanish]

A sequel that knows exactly what it is: an unapologetically masculine continuation of a cinematic legacy built on violence, power, and epic battles. It works because it doesn’t force itself to be more than that.
‘Gladiator II’ fights but fails to capture the magic of the first film.

Once you get past the dazzling visuals, it basically just resets the mythology for a new set of heroes and villains in similar settings, dealing with many of the same themes and sociopolitical struggles as its predecessor.
Scott and his collaborators pander so unabashedly to our bloodlust that it rings all the more hollow when Gladiator II suddenly fancies itself a civics lesson.
Even if Gladiator II is essentially an unapologetic retread of its predecessor, all of these actors are fun to watch -- though none stands taller, literally or figuratively, than Denzel Washington.
At the very least, you will walk out of “Gladiator II” entertained – but you won’t be much else.
It’s so grandiose, the audience at my screening started applauding before a single fight had begun.

Sir Ridley is 87 years old, and we only mention this because there's a vibrancy and verve to so much of this sequel that you'd swear the unbelievably prolific filmmaker has a personal fountain of youth in his Malibu mansion's backyard.

Its existence makes the original film even better. The two pictures complement each other well, and taken as one whole story it becomes the high art epic that we all incorrectly remember the original film being.
Gladiator II strips away the artsy veneer and simply exists as an action picture. I think it’s far more entertaining than the original.
A movie bursting with just enough spectacle to keep it from being boring but, when you try to get anything out of it thematically, slips through your fingers like the sand in a warrior's hands.

The long belated sequel begins with a series of painterly depictions of various clips of its far superior predecesor, and from that point on it never ceases to remind you that you've already seen a better version of all of this. [Full Review in Spanish]
Strong as Washington is, this is firmly Mescal’s movie.
Gladiator II does not take itself seriously, and in many ways it is absolutely ridiculous. And that's probably why I liked it.
Without a star who can summon a little more of that Crowian command, it’s a fool’s errand. Sad to say, no one is unleashing hell at Mescal’s signal.
Lucius’s glorious, bloody, twisty, escapist Roman road to victory holds audiences captive from beginning to end.

Cleary leaned into "let's make a gripping action/adventure flick" instead of a prestige sword-and-sandals epic like the original. Still quite enjoyable on that level, with a slithery charismatic turn from Denzel Washington buoying the non-fighting scenes.

Gladiator II might not be its predecessor’s equal in all regards, but Scott remains unparalleled at threading the needle between myth and history without sacrificing any of the spectacle. That, folks, is entertainment.

There are bad movies that are entertaining and bad movies that are a drag, and I wish I could tell you which one this unasked-for sequel to the best-picture-winning 2000 film is. The truth is, it's both.
It functions like a pale imitator.
The visual splendors of this new film easily equal and sometimes exceed the indelible visions of the first film
My complaint isn't so much that this one doesn't reach the same heights as the first but that the drop-off is so steep, it signals a lack of ambition that comes across as almost cynical.

The dialogue can be uttered with a straight face, for the most part, and the visual effects look appropriately pricey (big tusky battle rhinos and snarling death baboons don't come cheap nowadays). What the movie lacks is a reason to be.
Washington gives a baddie for the ages.
The performance by Washington alone is worth the price of admission, and when combined with the great sword fight, it creates an unforgettable box office experience.
This isn’t the dream of Rome, but at least it’s not a complete nightmare.
It may be unfair to judge Mescal boring here, because unlike Washington or Pascal he just isn’t given anything interesting to play.

The film is so vast and monumental you almost forget the first movie’s artful use of mindful design; battles, intrigue and alliances that happen for a reason, and actor’s performance’s that are central to the storyteller’s core.
If Denzel Washington was not in this movie it would be a particularly forgettable film.
A himbo movie: dumb as hell, but so beautiful I didn't care. It's accidental fascist apologia, and I'll probably see it twice.
Now, to be honest, I was not all that jazzed about seeing Gladiator II...So, was I pleasantly surprised? Um…sure.

Like its predecessor, Gladiator II features some of the most epic and action-packed battles of the year. It does struggle, however, when it gets too caught up in trying to connect all the dots with the first film.
“Gladiator II” is saddled by callbacks that weigh it down with soapy drama when it should be showcasing the sword, the sandal, and the arena.
With Gladiator II, Scott throws everything he can at the screen to ensure viewers are suitably… entertained. Just don’t expect to dwell on a lot of this long after it ends.

A qualified thumbs up for this sequel that can’t match the Oscar-winning best picture that spawned it, but the crowd will roar thanks to razzle-dazzle director Ridley Scott and a sensational, scene-stealing Denzel Washington as a villain worth cheering.
Ridley Scott's late-coming sequel 'Gladiator II' stakes few claims to necessity, but the action epic definitely entertains.
Stories told in the same world can echo each other and, if done well, overcome those similarities. But Gladiator II is shockingly boring for a purported sword-and-sandals epic.
If there’s justice, Washington will be awarded on Oscar night.

Scott strikes out by both hewing too closely to the source material and by toeing the line between drama and comedy. A failure that further tilts his filmography towards the bloated, CGI-heavy period-pic failures that have come to define his later work.
[For] all my misgivings, I was entertained by Gladiator II.
While Gladiator II does fall short in many ways, yes, we are still entertained.
On my short list of film directors who criminally have never won an Academy Award for their work, Ridley Scott is right at the top.
The very best and worst of Ridley Scott is on display here. It sways too much into tedious and bland rather than poignant or audacious.
Every element in Gladiator II says, “How about we try the same things we did before, only not as well?” Mr. Scott wants to be thrilling, but the effort is more palpable than the results.
It’s two-parts impressive spectacle and one-part implausible hokum.
There’s no slack to the yak in this dramatically turgid and inadvertently comical miscalculation, easily the dumbest, detail-challenged sword-and-sandal release of the century so far.
I loved every battle sequence, but there aren’t enough of them to justify the 2.5-hour running time or the endless hours of empty chatter
After all this time, the most that Scott can come up with is a mediocre echo of what he's already accomplished.
“Gladiator II’s” biggest failures are its absence of depth and gravitas.
...if you are going to take a Best Picture winning title and slap a "II" on the end of it, people are going to expect more. Something elevated. Something worthy. ​This is not that.

I hung there, for some of the acting, for some of the callbacks, and for the many individual moments, or single shots, that could only have come from Ridley Scott. And in the end, yes, you too may be moderately entertained.

One of the prime reasons that “Gladiator II” works despite all the familiar plot points and the near-corny late developments is that these great actors pour themselves into their respective roles, never winking at the camera.
Scott’s increasingly leaden direction can’t add any nuance, and instead sloppily lumps together the po-faced grandeur of Quo Vadis and the unhinged debauchery of Caligula.
It’s not on par with its 2000 predecessor, but the script by David Scarpa, who collaborated last year on “Napoleon” with director Ridley Scott, does connect the dots smartly with blood and purpose.
Gladiator II is another handsomely made but emotionally inert historical epic.
A slightly silly but entertaining sequel to Ridley Scott’s Oscar-winning "Gladiator."
Gladiator II can't replicate the sorrows of the first movie or reach its noble heights.
Scott has made the act of movie watching an enjoyable one—even if you forget just about everything a week after watching it.
The cgi was awful, and characters aren't as strong, but still a worthy sequel to the original with tons of fun action!

Nostalgia is another character that interweaves itself in this storyline. It makes the film a popcorn blockbuster that will pass the time, but I’m not sure it will stand the test of time as a classic like Gladiator.
Those overbaked and confounded conveniences were not necessary to dramatically revisit a successful legend such as this one, which already had adrenaline and spectacle on its face value alone.

In this way, “Gladiator II” coasts: never good, never terrible, always a little disappointing, with speeches that fall flat and gladiator battles that are like watching the World Series when your team isn’t in it.
Scott strives mightily to recapture the magic that the 2000 movie created for so many people, but falls short, despite one spectacular performance.

Although Gladiator II doesn’t quite reach the lofty heights of Gladiator, it reminds audiences what Ridley Scott can do behind the camera, with solid performances and eye-popping visuals guaranteed to entertain audiences.
Sure Gladiator II has some head-scratching moments. But that's par for the Ridley Scott course. Its balanced very well, maybe even better than the first, with great blood thirsty action and heart.
[W]e've seen this all before—done better 24 years ago and as part of the ongoing trend of legacy sequels.
A cautionary tale about what happens to lightweight TV actors when they come up against a bona fide movie star.
Gladiator II doesn’t need to scream “are you not entertained” because it knows we are. Gladiator II delivers exactly what you want from a blockbuster.
Scott once again creates an epic film "fit for the Gods," ensuring accuracy.
If one were to engage with the deeper meanings being explored throughout the film, beyond the blood and gore of the arena, Gladiator II would be hailed as a truly remarkable piece of cinema.
Bigger, louder and longer than the original film, Ridley Scott’s Gladiator II has sword and sandal sequelitis.
For fans of the original, the nostalgic callbacks and epic set pieces may be enough to satisfy, even if this sequel rarely achieves the soul-stirring impact of its predecessor.

The film itself is a son, made from the same DNA, in the same image. It is the only “Gladiator” sequel that could possibly exist and exactly what you expect, for better or for worse. Are you not entertained?
Most dismayingly, the grand emotional sweep of the first film is nowhere to be found in Gladiator II; the sequel is epic in length and spectacle, but not in feeling.

Enjoying the evil wit of Macrinus and figuring out what motivates him gives Gladiator II whatever scant novelty it possesses. The film otherwise is mostly violent déjà vu, selling moviegoers the same story it peddled nearly a quarter-century ago.
A weak, inconsequential film. [Full review in Spanish]

Crafted with care & ambition, the follow-up to Ridley Scott’s iconic 2000 film has finally arrived & it delivers. Cinematic experience designed not just to ride on the coattails of its predecessor but to stand on its own as an entry worth experiencing.
For fans of the original it’s more of the same. For everyone else it’s all Denzel and little else.
That's not to say that Mescal doesn't have magnetism; in fact, his performance is one of the highlights of the film. But his character is under-written.
From action sequences filled with kinetic energy to powerful performances, Gladiator II makes its mark as a must-see movie of 2024. Action-packed, thrilling, and a must for fans of the original film.
Gladiator II is absurd, stale, and, sadly, not a little bit pathetic in this day and age.

Scott... is still skilled enough to turn what amounts to the same script you’d have seen in a direct-to-DVD sequel circa 2005 into something that looks expensive and professional, he’s no longer at the point where he can make it sing

Don’t go to Ridley Scott’s sequel for historical accuracy. Go for the thrills of another underdog Colosseum fighter (Paul Mescal) battling the Empire. The film doesn’t quite match the Oscar-worthy heights of the 2000 original, but it’s still entertaining.

Big, brawny, blood-spattering and furiously entertaining, to (just like the Roman Colosseum) keep the crowd roaring, revved and ripped for the eye-popping, head-lopping, flesh-tearing show they’re watching.

I was entranced by the performances and thrilled by the set designs and intensity of the action pieces. The story is a little overcomplicated, reducing the impact of its entirety thanks to a lack of development and focus on the many established arcs.
While Gladiator II does not dazzle, it's quite convincing. [Full review in Spanish]

If you adhere to the philosophy of some of the Roman emperors — and modern-day leaders — as long as it’s entertaining and a sensory overload, there’s enough here with which to have a good time. Just don’t think too hard about it.

Denzel Washington’s extravagant performance likewise makes Gladiator II worthwhile. Still, not even its excessively violent action sequences, beautiful cinematography, and masterful set and costume design can save the sequel from how boring it is.
It is ultimately enlivened, if only to a point, by the sheer nuttiness of some of the imagery presented and the sight of Denzel Washington cheerfully chewing much of the scenery in a supporting turn.
Since Paramount, Scott, and good old-fashioned corporate greed kick-started the idea of continuing the “Gladiator” franchise, you would think we’d get something more than a rehash of the first film.
Foibles and fumbles and all, however, “Gladiator II” is still dumb fun. But it’s no match for the high standards set by the original.

It’s not a bad movie, they’re not bad performances. It’s OK. It’s fine. I guess, it’s mostly good enough. But is this way you want to feel about a big budget historical epic from the director who has previously brought you iconic cinema? Not even close.
Gladiator II is a big, brawny, and sprawling epic film that should make a lot of audiences happy with action and just the right amount of drama and theme.
Don't we all love a great sword-and-sandal spectacular? Mescal, Nielsen, Washington and Pascal are terrific. Baboons, a rhinoceros, two Caligulas, this film has it all.
In the end, the sequel’s biggest sin is its familiarity, which confirms just how unnecessary it is.

This just keeps following the plot points of his first Gladiator. With these outlandish characters and frivolous detours mixed with such stoic characters, it’s uneven. But Ridley Scott, Maestro of Action, is still in the fight, and he’s done it again.

These fights and performances land Gladiator II on the more positive end of Scott’s mid-tier filmography: fun to watch, but never quite displaying the heart that made Gladiator, Alien, and Blade Runner classics.
Gladiator II arguably will not have the same effect [as the first film], but it is a handsome continuation of the story with some fabulously crafted set pieces.

The Ridley Scott sequel delivers exactly what fans want: a gripping story, brutal action, and compelling performances. It answers Maximus’ iconic question, “Are you not entertained?” with a resounding yes.
Feeling like a remake of the first film, Gladiator II is not as epic or politically savvy as you'd think a "fighting for control of Rome" story would be.
Ridley Scott reminds us that reliving the successes of the past is a dangerous task and that sometimes the coliseum is best left in memory, intact in its glory. [Full review in Spanish]
Gladiator 2 (or as it’s spelled in the opening title, GladIIator) sadly comes off as less a reinvention of the original than a curiously literal retread of its plot beats, characters, and themes.
A very enjoyable movie that's well-tied to its predecessor. [Full review in Spanish]
With Sir Ridley Scott once again directing the Colosseum extravaganza, could it possibly be as good as his first Roman spectacular? Well, it’s not. But, boy, does it put up a good fight.
Although not as fresh or original, this sequel is filled with charismatic, odd, and attractive characters... [Full review in Spanish]

GLADIATOR II is an absolute epic. Ridley Scott is in top form with masterful directing and incredible set pieces.

Paul Mescal delivers a career best performance alongside a tour de force showing by Denzel Washington. Nielsen and Pascal were great as well
That’s the film all over: bloodier, more fiendishly stuffed with neoclassical badassery than its predecessor.

It’s equal parts compelling, ridiculous and uproariously pleasurable, often to the point where you can almost hear director Ridley Scott shouting, “Are you not entertained?” And, in truth, there are very few viewers who will not be.
This has everything one would want from a Ridley Scott film. It is just as engaging as the original film and has such a wonderful ensemble. One of the best films of the year!
Relying heavily on past glory, rather than charting its own unique way, Scott’s film entertains in spurts but swiftly leaves one’s mind once you exit the arena.

While Ridley Scott delivers spectacular gladiatorial action and Denzel Washington steals every scene, 'Gladiator 2's derivative plot and inability to escape its predecessor's shadow prevent it from achieving the same legendary status as the original.
In such a spectacle, corny dialogue, campy performances, ridiculous scenarios and liberties with historical fact aren’t bugs, they’re features.
Consider me somewhat entertained.
Denzel Washington steals the movie. He is so much fun to watch.
At the age of 86, the old boy still knows how to craft a sword-and-sandals epic, so to hell with the facts.
